resource.chars:
Any institution of learning will
succeed only as its alumni succeed-
ed for they represent the finished
product. On the other hand, each
alumnus carries the brand of his
Alma Mater and must see to the
success of it.

A. D. Radebaugh, ’l4, resigned
his position as County Agent of
Cecil County and has accepted the
position of Director of the Bureau
of Raw Products of the service de-
partment of the American Can Com-
pany which is the largest tin can
company in the United States. He
is located in the Citizens’ Bank
Building in Baltimore.
Radebaugh brought fame to him-
self recently when he exhibited at
the International Corn Show in Chi-
cago the ear of corn which won the
Grand Championship, an honor
which gives a Maryland man the
best ear of corn in the World in
1925.

Windell Powell, ’25, journeyed to
Schenectady, New York, on Jan-
uary 1 to take up his duties with
the General Electric Company. Pow-
ell won a host of friends while at
Maryland. He received a great dd’al
of practical knowledge in the elec-
trical line in his connection with
general service.

H. O. Yates, jr., ’24, who was em-
ployed for some time after grad-
uation at our greenhouses is now
assistant professor of Horticulture
at the University of Maine, and is in
charge of all the floriculture and
landscape gardening work.

News comes from the Registrar’s
office that Ruth Fuhrman died at
her home i.i Washington some time
during Decemoer. She was grad-
uated from the Horticultural course
of the College of Agriculture in
1923.
